settings.heading: What are the main symptoms of peripheral neuropathy?

settings.text: An examination of your physical condition and a review of your medical history are typically used to diagnose peripheral neuropathy. In order to confirm the diagnosis, your doctor might also request additional tests like blood tests or nerve conduction studies. Readers of Welzo should read this article to learn more about Peripheral neuropathyPeripheral neuropathy's most typical symptoms include pain and numbness in the hands or feet. Muscle weakness, loss of balance, and issues with coordination are possible additional symptoms. The symptoms of peripheral neuropathy can range from a dull ache to sharp pain or burning. It may also result in paralysis in some situations. People with peripheral neuropathy may have trouble falling asleep because the condition frequently gets worse at night. Although there is no known treatment for peripheral neuropathy, there are ways to manage the symptoms. These consist of prescription drugs, physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications.

settings.heading: What are the most common causes of peripheral neuropathy?

settings.text: An examination of your physical condition and a review of your medical history are typically used to diagnose peripheral neuropathy. Readers of Welzo should read this article to learn more about Peripheral neuropathyThere are many different causes of peripheral neuropathy, including diabetes, cancer, autoimmune diseases, and infections. It may be possible to reduce peripheral neuropathy symptoms by treating the underlying condition. Peripheral neuropathy occasionally has an underlying cause that is unknown.

settings.heading: What are the treatment options for peripheral neuropathy?

settings.text:
An examination of your physical condition and a review of your medical history are typically used to diagnose peripheral neuropathy. In order to confirm the diagnosis, your doctor might also request additional tests like blood tests or nerve conduction studies. Readers of Welzo should read this article to learn more about Peripheral neuropathyAlthough there is no known cure for peripheral neuropathy, there are treatments that can help manage the symptoms. These consist of prescription drugs, physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications. Antidepressants, seizure medications, pain relievers, and topical treatments are among the medications used to treat peripheral neuropathy. Strength and dexterity in the muscles can be enhanced with physical therapy. Altering one's lifestyle, such as giving up smoking and consuming alcohol sparingly, may also be beneficial.

A condition known as peripheral neuropathy results in pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hands and feet. Diabetes is the most typical cause of peripheral neuropathy. Medication, physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications are all used in the treatment of symptoms. Peripheral neuropathy is incurable.
